title: Conflicts Of Law
description: Conflicts Of Law flashcards for bar exam prep

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 001. Full Faith and Credit Clause
cards.front: Full Faith and Credit Clause – Overview
cards.backPlain: 1. Basic Rule: 1.1 Under the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the U.S. Constitution, a state court judgment that is valid, final, and on the merits must be recognized and enforced in other states. 1.2 A court in one state may not retry an issue that was properly decided in another state court proceeding. 1.3 If an issue is barred from re-litigation by virtue of full faith and credit, no further choice-of-law analysis is necessary as to that issue or judgment. 2. Scope and Application: 2.1 Although the Full Faith and Credit Clause formally applies only to state courts, federal courts follow the same basic framework under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1738 and 1963 when issuing or recognizing judgments. 2.2 Courts must give full faith and credit to prior proceedings of U.S. states and territories unless a valid defense to recognition or enforcement applies (e.g., lack of jurisdiction, not on the merits, or no final judgment).
cards.frontPrompt: What is the basic rule of the Full Faith and Credit Clause regarding state court judgments, what is its effect on relitigation and choice-of-law, and in general how broadly does it apply?
cards.cloze: 1. Basic Rule: 1.1 Under the {{c1::Full Faith and Credit Clause}} of the {{c2::U.S. Constitution}}, a state court judgment that is {{c3::valid, final, and on the merits}} must be {{c4::recognized and enforced}} in other states. 1.2 A court in one state may not {{c5::retry an issue that was properly decided}} in another state court proceeding. 1.3 If an issue is barred from re-litigation by virtue of {{c1::full faith and credit}}, no further {{c6::choice-of-law}} analysis is necessary as to that issue or judgment. 2. Scope and Application: 2.1 Although the Full Faith and Credit Clause formally applies only to {{c7::state courts}}, {{c8::federal courts}} follow the same basic framework under {{c9::28 U.S.C. §§ 1738 and 1963}} when issuing or recognizing judgments. 2.2 Courts must give full faith and credit to prior proceedings of U.S. states and territories unless a valid {{c10::defense to recognition or enforcement}} applies (e.g., {{c11::lack of jurisdiction, not on the merits, or no final judgment}}).
cards.easyContent: The Full Faith and Credit Clause requires states (and, by statute, federal courts) to recognize and enforce valid, final, on-the-merits judgments from other states, preventing relitigation and usually making separate choice-of-law analysis unnecessary for those issues.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Full Faith and Credit Clause, a state must recognize and enforce other states’ court judgments that are valid, final, and on the merits, and may not relitigate issues properly decided elsewhere. When full faith and credit applies, no further choice-of-law analysis is needed for that judgment or issue. Although the Clause formally binds only state courts, federal courts follow the same basic framework under 28 U.S.C. §§ 1738 and 1963, and courts must give full faith and credit unless a valid defense to recognition (such as lack of jurisdiction, not on the merits, or lack of finality) applies.
cards.hardContent: The Full Faith and Credit Clause of the U.S. Constitution requires that a state court judgment that is valid, final, and on the merits be recognized and enforced in other states. A recognizing court may not retry an issue that was properly decided in another state’s court, and if full faith and credit bars relitigation of a judgment or issue, no additional choice-of-law analysis is needed for that matter. Formally, the Clause applies to state courts, but federal courts follow the same general framework through 28 U.S.C. §§ 1738 and 1963 when issuing and recognizing judgments, and courts must accord full faith and credit to judgments of U.S. states and territories unless a specific defense to recognition applies (e.g., lack of jurisdiction, judgment not on the merits, or judgment not final).
cards.mnemonic: Defenses to full faith and credit are J-M-F: lack of Jurisdiction, not on the Merits, or not Final.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) basic Full Faith and Credit rule, scope, and effect on choice-of-law (parent), and (2) defenses to recognition (jurisdiction, on the merits, finality) (child).
cards.clozeLite: A state must {{c1::recognize and enforce}} another state’s {{c2::valid, final, on-the-merits judgment}}, which {{c3::prevents relitigation}} and {{c4::eliminates further choice-of-law analysis}} for that issue.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 002. Choice of Law Theories
cards.backPlain: 1. In General: 1.1 When a transaction or event is connected to more than one jurisdiction, and the potentially applicable laws differ, a choice-of-law (COL) analysis is required to determine which law to apply. 1.2 There are three main approaches; generally, states use one of the following COL tests: 1.2.1 Vested Rights Approach of the First Restatement; 1.2.2 Most Significant Relationship Approach of the Second Restatement; and 1.2.3 Governmental Interest Approach. 2. Diversity cases: 2.1 A federal court exercising diversity jurisdiction over non-federal claims must apply the COL approach of the state in which it sits. 2.2 Example: A federal court in State A exercising diversity jurisdiction over a tort claim filed by a citizen of State A against a citizen of State B must apply State A's COL approach.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a choice-of-law analysis required, what are the three main choice-of-law approaches, and which approach does a federal court use in a diversity case?
cards.cloze: 1. In General: 1.1 When a transaction or event is connected to more than one {{c1::jurisdiction}}, and the potentially applicable laws differ, a {{c2::choice-of-law (COL)}} analysis is required to determine which law to apply. 1.2 There are three main approaches; generally, states use one of the following COL tests: 1.2.1 {{c3::Vested Rights Approach}} of the {{c4::First Restatement}}; 1.2.2 {{c5::Most Significant Relationship Approach}} of the {{c6::Second Restatement}}; and 1.2.3 {{c7::Governmental Interest Approach}}. 2. Diversity cases: 2.1 A federal court exercising {{c8::diversity jurisdiction}} over non-federal claims must apply the COL approach of the {{c9::state in which it sits}}. 2.2 Example: A federal court in State A exercising diversity jurisdiction over a tort claim filed by a citizen of State A against a citizen of State B must apply {{c10::State A's}} COL approach.
cards.easyContent: A choice-of-law analysis is needed when a case is connected to more than one jurisdiction whose laws conflict, and states generally use one of three approaches: vested rights, most significant relationship, or governmental interest.
cards.mediumContent: When an event or transaction implicates more than one jurisdiction with differing laws, a choice-of-law analysis is required. States generally follow one of three tests: the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, or the Governmental Interest Approach. In diversity cases involving state-law claims, a federal court must apply the choice-of-law approach of the state in which it sits.
cards.hardContent: A choice-of-law analysis is required when a transaction or event is connected to more than one jurisdiction and the potentially applicable laws differ. States generally adopt one of three choice-of-law approaches: the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, which looks to where the relevant right vested; the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, which chooses the law of the state with the closest relationship to the dispute; and the Governmental Interest Approach, which focuses on which state has the greatest interest in applying its law. In diversity cases involving non-federal claims, a federal court sitting in State A must apply State A’s choice-of-law approach, as illustrated when a federal diversity tort suit between citizens of different states uses the forum state’s COL methodology.
cards.mnemonic: COL is V-M-G: Vested, Most-significant, Governmental.
cards.clozeLite: A choice-of-law analysis is required when {{c1::more than one jurisdiction's laws conflict}}. States use {{c2::vested rights}}, {{c3::most significant relationship}}, or {{c4::governmental interest}}. A federal diversity court uses {{c5::the forum state's choice-of-law approach}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 003. Recognition of Foreign Judgments
cards.backPlain: 1. In General: 1.1 Judgments of foreign nations are not given full faith and credit, but may be recognized on comity principles (i.e., voluntary recognition). 1.2 In choosing whether to recognize a foreign judgment, courts look at: 1.2.1 Whether the foreign court had jurisdiction; and 1.2.2 Whether fair procedures were used in adjudicating the case. 2. Effect of recognition: 2.1 If a foreign judgment is recognized, it is enforced the same as another state's valid judgment would be.
cards.frontPrompt: Are foreign-country judgments entitled to full faith and credit, and on what basis and conditions may U.S. courts recognize and enforce them?
cards.cloze: 1. In General: 1.1 Judgments of {{c1::foreign nations}} are {{c2::not given full faith and credit}}, but may be recognized on {{c3::comity}} principles (i.e., voluntary recognition). 1.2 In choosing whether to recognize a foreign judgment, courts look at: 1.2.1 Whether the foreign court had {{c4::jurisdiction}}; and 1.2.2 Whether {{c5::fair procedures}} were used in adjudicating the case. 2. Effect of recognition: 2.1 If a foreign judgment is {{c6::recognized}}, it is {{c7::enforced the same as another state's valid judgment}} would be.
cards.easyContent: Foreign-country judgments are not entitled to full faith and credit but may be recognized under principles of comity if the foreign court had jurisdiction and used fair procedures; once recognized, they are enforced like a sister-state judgment.
cards.mediumContent: Judgments from foreign nations do not receive automatic full faith and credit, but U.S. courts may recognize them as a matter of comity. In deciding whether to recognize a foreign judgment, courts ask whether the foreign court had proper jurisdiction and whether it used fair procedures. If the judgment is recognized, it is enforced in the same manner as a valid judgment from another U.S. state.
cards.hardContent: Judgments of foreign nations are not constitutionally entitled to full faith and credit, but U.S. courts may voluntarily recognize them under principles of comity. Recognition turns on whether the foreign court had proper jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter and whether the proceedings employed fair procedures consistent with due process. When a foreign judgment is recognized, it is treated and enforced like a valid sister-state judgment, with the same preclusive and enforcement effects in the recognizing forum.
cards.mnemonic: Foreign JC: Jurisdiction and fair Court procedures, then comity treats like sister-state.
cards.clozeLite: Foreign-country judgments are not {{c1::entitled to full faith and credit}} but may be recognized under {{c2::comity}} if the foreign court had {{c3::jurisdiction}} and used {{c4::fair procedures}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 004. Vested Rights Approach (First Restatement)
cards.backPlain: Under the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, a court applies the law of the state where the relevant right "vested"—typically the place of the last act or event that created the right being asserted. This basic "last act" principle is then implemented by subject-matter–specific rules, such as the place of injury for torts, the place of contracting or performance for contracts, the situs for property, and the state of incorporation for internal corporate affairs.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, what is the basic idea of how a court chooses which state’s law to apply, and how is that idea implemented across different subject areas?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach}}, a court applies the law of the state where the relevant right {{c2::vested}}—typically the place of the {{c3::last act or event}} that created the right being asserted. This basic {{c4::"last act"}} principle is then implemented by {{c5::subject-matter–specific rules}} (e.g., torts, contracts, property, corporations).
cards.easyContent: The First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach tells courts to apply the law of the state where the right vested—usually the place of the last act or event—and then uses specific rules for torts, contracts, property, and corporations to identify that place.
cards.mediumContent: Under the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, courts apply the law of the state where the right at issue vested, ordinarily the place of the last act or event giving rise to that right. This general "last act" principle is then implemented through subject-specific rules, such as the place of injury in torts, the place of contracting or performance in contracts, the situs for property, and the state of incorporation for corporate internal affairs.
cards.hardContent: The First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach is a territorial choice-of-law method under which the forum applies the law of the state where the relevant rights vested—usually the state where the last act or event occurred that created the rights asserted in the lawsuit. The vesting concept is operationalized by different rules depending on the substantive area (torts, contracts, property, corporate internal affairs), each of which identifies the place where rights vest in that context.
cards.mnemonic: Vested rights: follow the LAST ACT—injury, making, situs, incorporation.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) general vested-rights principle, (2) torts and contracts implementing rules, and (3) property and corporate implementing rules.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach}}, courts apply the law of the state where the {{c2::right vested}}, usually the {{c3::place of the last act or event}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 005. Most Significant Relationship Approach (Second Restatement)
cards.backPlain: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, a court applies the law of the state with the most significant relationship to the specific issue. Courts first consider general Second Restatement choice-of-law factors—such as the relevant policies of the forum and other interested jurisdictions, the policies of the substantive field, the ease of applying a candidate law, and whether applying a given law promotes certainty, uniformity, and predictability. They then refine the analysis with subject-specific contacts for different substantive areas, including torts (place of injury and conduct causing injury, plus parties’ domiciles), contracts (places of contracting, negotiation, performance, subject matter location, and parties’ domiciles), property (state most significantly related to the property transaction), and corporations (state of incorporation).
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Second Restatement, what is the Most Significant Relationship Approach in general, and how do courts use both general factors and subject-specific contacts to choose the applicable law?
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach}}, a court applies the law of the state with the {{c2::most significant relationship}} to the specific issue. Courts first consider {{c3::general choice-of-law factors}}—such as the {{c4::relevant policies of the forum and other interested jurisdictions}}, the {{c5::policies of the substantive field}}, the {{c6::ease of applying a candidate law}}, and whether applying a given law promotes {{c7::certainty, uniformity, and predictability}}. They then refine the analysis with {{c8::subject-specific contacts}} for different substantive areas, including {{c9::torts, contracts, property, and corporations}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, a court applies the law of the state with the most significant relationship to the issue, using both general policy-based factors and subject-specific contacts (for torts, contracts, property, and corporations).
cards.mediumContent: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, courts select the law of the state with the most significant relationship to the issue. They look first to general factors: (1) policies of the forum and other interested states; (2) policies of the substantive field; (3) ease of applying the law; and (4) whether applying a given law promotes certainty, uniformity, and predictability. Then they refine the inquiry using subject-specific contacts for different areas—torts, contracts, property, and corporations.
cards.hardContent: The Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach directs courts to apply the law of the state with the most significant relationship to the particular issue. The court evaluates general factors such as: (1) the relevant policies of the forum and of other interested jurisdictions; (2) the policies underlying the substantive field of law; (3) the ease of applying the candidate law; and (4) whether applying that law advances certainty, uniformity, and predictability. After weighing these general principles, the court turns to more tailored contacts depending on the substantive area—torts, contracts, property, and corporations—to determine which state has the most significant relationship overall.
cards.mnemonic: MSR: Most Significant Relationships, then area-specific Contacts and Policies.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) general Second Restatement Most Significant Relationship factors; (2) tort-specific contacts; (3) contract-specific contacts; (4) property- and corporation-specific rules.
cards.clozeLite: Under the Second Restatement’s {{c1::Most Significant Relationship}} approach, courts weigh {{c2::general policy factors}} and {{c3::subject-specific contacts}} to choose the applicable law.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 006. Governmental Interest Approach
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule: Under the Governmental Interest Approach, the court analyzes the policies behind the conflicting laws in each forum and how those policies would be furthered by application to the case at hand. 1.1 How it works: 1.1.1 Courts start with the presumption that the forum's law should apply. 1.1.2 The court may examine the policies behind its laws and those of the other forum involved. 1.1.3 If another forum has an interest, the court will reconsider the forum's policies to determine whether it has a legitimate interest in applying its own law. 1.1.4 The court may then apply the other forum's laws, the forum's laws, or a modified version of either. 2. Substantive areas of law: The approach and analysis do not vary or add additional factors based on specific areas of law. 2.1 Exam tip: If the Governmental Interest Approach arises on your exam, be prepared to discuss each forum's interest in having its laws applied given the facts presented.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Governmental Interest Approach to choice of law, and how does a court apply it to decide which state’s law governs?
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule: Under the {{c1::Governmental Interest Approach}}, the court analyzes the {{c2::policies behind the conflicting laws in each forum}} and how those policies would be furthered by application to the case at hand. 1.1 How it works: 1.1.1 Courts start with the {{c3::presumption that the forum's law should apply}}. 1.1.2 The court may {{c4::examine the policies behind its laws and those of the other forum involved}}. 1.1.3 If another forum has an interest, the court will {{c5::reconsider the forum's policies to determine whether it has a legitimate interest in applying its own law}}. 1.1.4 The court may then apply the {{c6::other forum's laws, the forum's laws, or a modified version of either}}. 2. Substantive areas of law: The approach and analysis {{c7::do not vary or add additional factors based on specific areas of law}}. 2.1 Exam tip: If the Governmental Interest Approach arises on your exam, be prepared to {{c8::discuss each forum's interest in having its laws applied given the facts presented}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the Governmental Interest Approach, courts choose the law of the state whose policies would be most furthered by applying its law, starting with a presumption in favor of the forum’s own law.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Governmental Interest Approach, a court begins with a presumption that the forum’s law applies. It then analyzes the policies behind the forum’s law and the laws of other interested states and asks whether each state has a legitimate interest in having its law applied on the facts. Depending on whose interests are truly implicated, the court may apply the forum’s law, another state’s law, or a modified version of either. The same basic analysis applies regardless of the substantive area of law.
cards.hardContent: Under the Governmental Interest Approach to choice of law, the court focuses on the policies underlying each jurisdiction’s laws rather than on mechanical contacts. The court starts with a presumption that the forum’s law should apply. It then examines the policies behind the forum’s law and those of any other involved state, assessing whether each state has a legitimate governmental interest in applying its law to the dispute. If another forum has an interest and the forum does not, the court will typically apply the other forum’s law; if both do, it may apply forum law or a modified rule that accounts for both sets of interests. This analysis does not change based on the area of law; on an exam, you should explicitly analyze each forum’s interest in having its law applied on the given facts.
cards.mnemonic: INTEREST: Identify forum, Note others, Test Each state’s Real Stakes Today.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::Governmental Interest Approach}}, a court presumes {{c2::forum law applies}} and compares {{c3::each state's policies and interests}} to decide {{c4::which law governs}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 007. Contractual Choice of Law Provisions
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule: Express choice of law provisions in contracts are generally adhered to regardless of the choice-of-law approach that would otherwise be applied by a court. Where no choice-of-law provision exists, courts will use one of the three choice-of-law approaches. 2. Exceptions: Choice-of-law provisions in the contract will not be applied or honored where: 2.1 Contrary to public policy: Applying the law of the contract-designated forum would conflict with a fundamental policy of a different forum that has a materially greater interest than the designated forum in determining the particular issue. 2.2 No substantial relationship: The contracting parties' chosen forum bears no substantial relationship to the parties or the transaction, such that there is no reasonable basis for the choice. 2.3 Lack of consent: There was no true consent by all parties to the choice of the designated forum; this can arise due to fraud, mistake, or contracts of adhesion. 3. Default rules: Express choice-of-law provisions are always enforced with regard to default (as opposed to mandatory) rules. Default rules are mere gap fillers that can be modified by agreement of the parties even in entirely local matters.
cards.frontPrompt: When will a court enforce an express contractual choice-of-law provision, and what are the main exceptions to enforcement?
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule: {{c1::Express choice-of-law provisions in contracts}} are generally {{c2::adhered to regardless of the choice-of-law approach}} that would otherwise be applied by a court. Where no choice-of-law provision exists, courts will use one of the {{c3::three choice-of-law approaches}}. 2. Exceptions: Choice-of-law provisions in the contract will not be applied or honored where: 2.1 {{c4::Contrary to public policy}}: Applying the law of the contract-designated forum would conflict with a {{c5::fundamental policy of a different forum that has a materially greater interest}} than the designated forum in determining the particular issue. 2.2 {{c6::No substantial relationship}}: The contracting parties' chosen forum bears {{c7::no substantial relationship to the parties or the transaction}}, such that there is no reasonable basis for the choice. 2.3 {{c8::Lack of consent}}: There was {{c9::no true consent by all parties to the choice of the designated forum}}; this can arise due to {{c10::fraud, mistake, or contracts of adhesion}}. 3. Default rules: Express choice-of-law provisions are always enforced with regard to {{c11::default (as opposed to mandatory) rules}}. Default rules are {{c12::gap fillers that can be modified by agreement of the parties}} even in entirely local matters.
cards.easyContent: Express contractual choice-of-law clauses are usually enforced, but they will be refused if they violate a fundamental public policy, lack a substantial relationship to the parties or transaction, or were not truly consented to.
cards.mediumContent: Courts generally enforce express choice-of-law provisions in contracts, regardless of which choice-of-law approach they otherwise use; if there is no such clause, they revert to a choice-of-law methodology. A court will decline to apply a chosen law if doing so (1) would conflict with a fundamental public policy of a state that has a materially greater interest in the issue, (2) the chosen state has no substantial relationship to the parties or transaction and there is no reasonable basis for the choice, or (3) the parties did not truly consent to the clause, such as in cases of fraud, mistake, or adhesion contracts. However, choice-of-law clauses are always enforceable as to default (non-mandatory) rules, which parties are free to modify by agreement.
cards.hardContent: Courts generally honor express contractual choice-of-law clauses, regardless of which background choice-of-law approach they otherwise apply. If there is no such clause, courts choose governing law under one of the standard approaches (e.g., First Restatement, Second Restatement, or Governmental Interest). A court will refuse to enforce a choice-of-law clause when: (1) applying the chosen law would contravene a fundamental policy of another state that has a materially greater interest in the particular issue than the chosen state; (2) the chosen forum has no substantial relationship to the parties or the transaction, so there is no reasonable basis for the choice; or (3) there was no genuine consent to the clause, such as where the choice was induced by fraud or mistake, or imposed in a contract of adhesion. Express clauses are always enforced with respect to default—rather than mandatory—rules, because default rules merely fill gaps and can be freely altered by party agreement, even in purely local contracts.
cards.mnemonic: P–R–C: Public policy, no Real tie, no Consent.
cards.clozeLite: Courts usually enforce {{c1::express contractual choice-of-law clauses}}, unless {{c2::fundamental public policy}} is violated, there is {{c3::no substantial relationship or reasonable basis}}, or {{c4::no true consent (fraud, mistake, adhesion)}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 008. Recognition of Divorce Judgments
cards.backPlain: Recognition of divorce-related judgments involves: 1. General rule for interstate recognition of divorce decrees: - Courts must give full faith and credit to a divorce decree from another state if (a) the decree is valid where rendered and (b) the rendering state had proper jurisdiction, which is ordinarily satisfied when at least one spouse is domiciled there. 2. Jurisdictional nuances: ex parte vs. consent divorces: - Ex parte divorces (only one spouse domiciled/appearing): the enforcing court may reexamine whether the rendering spouse’s domicile was bona fide, though domicile is presumed valid. - Consent divorces (both spouses appear): if at least one spouse is domiciled in the forum, the court has jurisdiction and other states must generally give full faith and credit. 3. Child custody determinations (related but governed by special statutes): - Custody jurisdiction is generally based on the child’s home state, and the home state’s decree receives full faith and credit. - The original court typically retains continuing jurisdiction unless it no longer has a significant connection with the child or the parties.
cards.frontPrompt: How are interstate divorce-related judgments recognized, including the general full faith and credit rule, jurisdiction in ex parte vs. consent divorces, and the special rules for child custody orders?
cards.cloze: Recognition of divorce-related judgments involves: 1. General rule for interstate recognition of divorce decrees: - Courts must give {{c1::full faith and credit}} to a divorce decree from another state if (a) the decree is {{c2::valid where rendered}} and (b) the rendering state had {{c3::proper jurisdiction}}, which is ordinarily satisfied when at least {{c4::one spouse is domiciled}} there. 2. Jurisdictional nuances: {{c5::ex parte}} vs. {{c6::consent}} divorces: - Ex parte divorces (only one spouse domiciled/appearing): the enforcing court may {{c7::reexamine domicile}} though domicile is {{c8::presumed bona fide}}. - Consent divorces (both spouses appear): if at least {{c9::one spouse is domiciled in the forum}}, the court has jurisdiction and other states must generally give full faith and credit. 3. Child custody determinations: - Custody jurisdiction is generally based on the child’s {{c10::home state}}, whose decree receives {{c11::full faith and credit}} and retains {{c12::continuing jurisdiction}} unless it loses a {{c13::significant connection}} with the child or the parties.
cards.easyContent: Interstate recognition of divorce judgments turns on full faith and credit: the decree must be valid where issued and that court must have jurisdiction, usually via a spouse’s domicile. Ex parte divorces allow reexamination of domicile, while consent divorces are more secure. Child custody follows home-state statutes, with the home state keeping jurisdiction until significant connections are lost.
cards.mediumContent: A state must recognize another state’s divorce decree if it is valid where rendered and the rendering court had jurisdiction, ordinarily satisfied if at least one spouse is domiciled there. In ex parte divorces, where only one spouse appears, the enforcing court may reexamine whether that spouse’s domicile was bona fide, though it is presumed valid. In consent divorces, where both spouses participate and at least one is domiciled in the forum, jurisdiction is secure and full faith and credit must generally be given. Child custody determinations are governed by reciprocal home-state statutes: the child’s home state has primary jurisdiction, other states must honor that decree, and the original court retains continuing jurisdiction unless it no longer has a significant connection with the child or disputing parties.
cards.hardContent: Recognition of divorce judgments across state lines is governed by full faith and credit and by specialized custody statutes. For divorce decrees, an enforcing state must recognize a sister-state decree if (1) the decree is valid under the law of the rendering state and (2) the rendering state had proper jurisdiction, usually met if at least one spouse is domiciled there. However, in ex parte divorces, based on the domicile and appearance of only one spouse, the enforcing state may inquire into and rebut the presumption that the rendering spouse’s domicile was genuine. In consent divorces, where both spouses appear and at least one spouse is domiciled in the forum, jurisdiction is solid and recognition is ordinarily mandatory. Child custody orders are treated separately under reciprocal statutes such as the UCCJEA. Generally, the child’s home state has jurisdiction to enter an initial custody order, other states must give that order full faith and credit, and the issuing court retains exclusive, continuing jurisdiction unless it no longer maintains a significant connection with the child or the parties involved.
cards.mnemonic: V+D: Valid where rendered plus Domicile; Home Holds for custody home state.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) general rule for recognizing divorce decrees; (2) ex parte vs. consent divorces and domicile; (3) child custody jurisdiction and modification rules.
cards.clozeLite: A state must recognize a sister-state divorce if it was {{c1::valid where rendered}} and the court had {{c2::jurisdiction via at least one spouse’s domicile}}. In {{c3::ex parte divorces}} domicile may be reexamined, but {{c4::consent divorces}} are secure. Child custody uses {{c5::home-state jurisdiction with continuing, exclusive control}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.topic: Full Faith and Credit – Defenses to Recognition or Enforcement
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 001-1. Full Faith and Credit – Defenses to Recognition or Enforcement
cards.front: Full Faith and Credit – Defenses to Recognition or Enforcement
cards.backPlain: Defenses to Full Faith and Credit (when a court is NOT required to enforce another state's judgment): 1. Lack of Jurisdiction 1.1 The rendering (prior) court lacked proper jurisdiction over the parties and/or subject matter; and 1.2 The party challenging the prior judgment did not fully and fairly litigate the jurisdiction issue in the prior court. 2. Judgment Not on the Merits 2.1 The prior judgment was not on the merits (i.e., it did not resolve the substance of the plaintiff's claim). 2.2 Example: A dismissal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction is not on the merits and need not be given full faith and credit as to the underlying claim. 3. No Final Judgment 3.1 The prior court’s judgment was not final. 3.2 A judgment is final when no further action by the court is necessary to resolve the litigation.
cards.frontPrompt: When may a court refuse to give full faith and credit to another state’s judgment, and what are the requirements for each defense (jurisdiction, merits, and finality)?
cards.cloze: Defenses to Full Faith and Credit (when a court is NOT required to enforce another state's judgment): 1. {{c1::Lack of Jurisdiction}} 1.1 The rendering court lacked proper {{c2::jurisdiction over the parties and/or subject matter}}; and 1.2 The party challenging the prior judgment did not {{c3::fully and fairly litigate the jurisdiction issue in the prior court}}. 2. {{c4::Judgment Not on the Merits}} 2.1 The prior judgment was not {{c5::on the merits}} (it did not resolve the {{c6::substance of the plaintiff's claim}}). 2.2 Example: A prior action {{c7::dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction}} is not on the merits. 3. {{c8::No Final Judgment}} 3.1 The prior court’s judgment was not {{c9::final}}. 3.2 A judgment is final when {{c10::no further action by the court is necessary to resolve the litigation}}.
cards.easyContent: A court can refuse full faith and credit if the original court lacked jurisdiction that was not fully litigated, if the judgment was not on the merits, or if the judgment was not final.
cards.mediumContent: There are three main defenses to full faith and credit. Recognition may be denied if: (1) the rendering court lacked personal or subject-matter jurisdiction and that jurisdiction issue was not fully and fairly litigated in the prior proceeding; (2) the prior judgment was not on the merits, such as a dismissal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction; or (3) the judgment was not final, meaning the court still had action to take to resolve the litigation.
cards.hardContent: A recognizing court may refuse to give full faith and credit to another state’s judgment only when one of the limited defenses applies. First, lack of jurisdiction: the rendering court must have lacked personal or subject-matter jurisdiction, and the party contesting recognition must not have fully and fairly litigated that jurisdictional issue in the prior proceeding. Second, judgment not on the merits: if the prior judgment did not adjudicate the substance of the plaintiff’s claim—such as a dismissal for lack of subject matter jurisdiction—it is not on the merits and need not be enforced as to the underlying claim. Third, no final judgment: a court need not recognize a judgment that is not final; a judgment is final when no further action by the rendering court is necessary to resolve the litigation.
cards.mnemonic: Defenses to full faith and credit are J-M-F: lack of Jurisdiction, not on the Merits, or not Final.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child card focusing on defenses to full faith and credit: lack of jurisdiction, not on the merits, no final judgment.
cards.clozeLite: Defenses to {{c1::full faith and credit}}: lack of {{c2::jurisdiction}} (not fully litigated), judgment {{c3::not on the merits}}, or {{c4::no final judgment}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.topic: Vested Rights Approach – General Rule and Last-Act Principle
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 004-1. Vested Rights Approach – General Rule and Last-Act Principle
cards.front: Vested Rights Approach – General Rule and Last-Act Principle
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule (First Restatement – Vested Rights): 1.1 Under the First Restatement's Vested Rights Approach, the court applies the law of the state where the act occurred or where the relationship that gave rise to the lawsuit developed. 1.2 Rights most often vest in the state where the last act or event occurred that gave rise to the rights being asserted in the lawsuit. 1.3 Conceptual focus: - The approach is territorial: it looks for the geographic location where a legal right came into existence. - Once the vesting state is identified, its law governs the substantive issues related to that right.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, what is the general rule for choosing applicable law, and what is meant by the “last act” where rights vest?
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule (First Restatement – Vested Rights): 1.1 Under the {{c1::First Restatement's Vested Rights Approach}}, the court applies the law of the state where the {{c2::act occurred}} or where the {{c3::relationship that gave rise to the lawsuit developed}}. 1.2 Rights most often vest in the state where the {{c4::last act or event occurred}} that gave rise to the rights being asserted in the lawsuit. 1.3 Conceptual focus: - The approach is {{c5::territorial}}: it looks for the geographic location where a legal right came into existence. - Once the {{c6::vesting state}} is identified, its law governs the {{c7::substantive issues}} related to that right.
cards.easyContent: The First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach applies the law of the state where the right arose—usually the place of the last act or event that created the right at issue.
cards.mediumContent: Under the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, a court applies the law of the state where the right vested, meaning the state where the act occurred or where the underlying relationship developed. In practice, this is usually the place of the last act or event that created the rights being asserted, and that state’s law governs the substantive issues tied to that right.
cards.hardContent: The First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach directs a court to apply the law of the state where rights vested. A right is deemed to vest where the act occurred or where the relationship that gave rise to the lawsuit developed, and in most cases this is pinpointed by the place of the last act or event necessary to create the plaintiff’s rights. The approach is territorial and event-focused: once the vesting state is identified through the last-act inquiry, that state’s law is applied to the substantive issues arising from that right.
cards.mnemonic: Vested rights vest where the last act occurs.
cards.clozeLite: Under the First Restatement, apply the {{c1::law of the state where the right vested}}, usually the {{c2::place of the last act creating the right}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.topic: Vested Rights Approach – Torts and Contracts
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 004-2. Vested Rights Approach – Torts and Contracts
cards.front: Vested Rights Approach – How It Applies in Torts and Contracts
cards.backPlain: 2. Application by Substantive Area – Torts and Contracts: 2.1 Torts (place of injury / last event causing liability): - The court applies the law of the state where the injury occurred. - Specifically, this is the state where the last event giving rise to liability occurred (e.g., the place where the plaintiff was actually injured), because that is where the tort right is deemed to vest. 2.2 Contracts (place of contracting vs. place of performance): - Default: The court applies the law of the state where the contract was formed (the place of making). - Performance disputes: If the dispute concerns performance (e.g., failure to perform, manner of performance), the court applies the law of the state where performance was due. - Rationale: The right to enforce the contract generally vests at formation, but performance-related rights vest at the place where performance is to occur.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, which state’s law applies in tort and contract cases, and how do place of injury, place of contracting, and place of performance matter?
cards.cloze: 2. Application by Substantive Area – Torts and Contracts: 2.1 {{c1::Torts}} (place of injury / last event causing liability): - The court applies the law of the state where the {{c2::injury occurred}}. - Specifically, this is the state where the {{c3::last event giving rise to liability}} occurred, because that is where the tort right is deemed to {{c4::vest}}. 2.2 {{c5::Contracts}} (place of contracting vs. place of performance): - Default: The court applies the law of the state where the {{c6::contract was formed}} (the place of making). - Performance disputes: If the dispute concerns {{c7::performance}}, the court applies the law of the state where {{c8::performance was due}}. - Rationale: The right to {{c9::enforce the contract}} generally vests at {{c10::formation}}, but performance-related rights vest at the {{c11::place of performance}}.
cards.easyContent: For torts, vested rights use the law of the place of injury—the last event causing liability. For contracts, use the law of the place of contracting by default, but if performance is at issue, use the law of the place where performance is due.
cards.mediumContent: Under the First Restatement’s vested-rights rules, tort claims are governed by the law of the state where the injury occurred, understood as the place of the last event giving rise to liability, because that is where the tort right vests. Contract disputes are governed by the law of the place of contracting by default, but when the dispute concerns performance, the law of the place where performance was due controls, since performance-related rights vest there.
cards.hardContent: Applying the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach by subject matter, tort rights vest in the state where the injury occurs, identified as the place of the last event necessary to create liability (such as the location where the plaintiff suffers harm), and that state’s law governs the tort issues. In contract cases, rights generally vest at the place of contracting, so the law of the state of formation governs most contract issues. However, when the dispute centers on performance—such as nonperformance or manner of performance—the relevant rights vest at the place where performance is due, and the law of that performance state applies to those issues.
cards.mnemonic: Torts hurt where injured; contracts bind where made or performed.
cards.clozeLite: Under vested rights, {{c1::tort}} issues use the {{c2::law of the place of injury}}, while {{c3::contract}} issues use {{c4::place of contracting}} or {{c5::place of performance}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.topic: Vested Rights Approach – Property and Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 004-3. Vested Rights Approach – Property and Corporations
cards.front: Vested Rights Approach – How It Applies to Property and Corporations
cards.backPlain: 2. Application by Substantive Area – Property and Corporations: 2.3 Property (situs rule): - The court applies the law of the state where the property is located (the situs). - This covers real property and, in general, rights that depend on the physical location of the property. 2.4 Tangible personal property: - The court applies the law of the state where the tangible personal property was located at the time of the relevant transaction. - Rationale: The right in the chattel is treated as vesting at the situs of the chattel at the time the right was created or transferred. 2.5 Corporations (internal affairs): - When the issue involves internal corporate affairs (e.g., shareholder voting, director duties, internal governance disputes), the court applies the law of the state where the corporation is incorporated. - This reflects the idea that the corporation’s internal rights and obligations vest under the law of the incorporating state.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, which state’s law governs property issues (including tangible personal property) and internal corporate affairs?
cards.cloze: 2. Application by Substantive Area – Property and Corporations: 2.3 {{c1::Property}} (situs rule): - The court applies the law of the state where the {{c2::property is located}} (the {{c3::situs}}). 2.4 {{c4::Tangible personal property}}: - The court applies the law of the state where the tangible personal property was located at the time of the {{c5::relevant transaction}}. - Rationale: The right in the chattel is treated as vesting at the {{c6::situs of the chattel}} when the right was {{c7::created or transferred}}. 2.5 {{c8::Corporations}} (internal affairs): - When the issue involves {{c9::internal corporate affairs}} (e.g., shareholder disputes, director duties), the court applies the law of the state where the {{c10::corporation is incorporated}}. - This reflects the idea that corporate internal rights and obligations {{c11::vest}} under the law of the {{c12::incorporating state}}.
cards.easyContent: For property, vested-rights uses the law of the situs—the state where the property is located. For tangible personal property, it’s the situs at the time of the transaction. For corporations’ internal affairs, it’s the law of the state of incorporation.
cards.mediumContent: Under the First Restatement’s Vested Rights Approach, property issues are governed by the law of the situs: the state where the property is located. For tangible personal property, the relevant law is that of the state where the item was located when the transaction creating or transferring the right occurred. Corporate internal affairs—such as shareholder and director rights—are governed by the law of the state of incorporation, because internal corporate rights are treated as vesting under that state’s law.
cards.hardContent: Applying the First Restatement’s vested-rights rules to property, a court uses the situs rule: it applies the law of the state where the property is located, on the theory that property rights vest where the property sits. For tangible personal property, the law of the state where the chattel was located at the time of the relevant transaction governs, because the right in the chattel is deemed to vest at the chattel’s situs when it is created or transferred. In corporate cases involving internal affairs—such as shareholder voting, dividend rights, or director fiduciary duties—the court applies the law of the state of incorporation, reflecting the principle that internal corporate rights and obligations vest under the law of the incorporating jurisdiction.
cards.mnemonic: SITS & BORN: Property sits (situs); corporations born (incorporation).
cards.clozeLite: Under vested rights, {{c1::property}} uses law of the {{c2::situs}}, and {{c3::corporate internal affairs}} use law of the {{c4::state of incorporation}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.topic: Most Significant Relationship – General Rule & Factors
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 005-1. Most Significant Relationship – General Rule & Factors
cards.front: Most Significant Relationship – General Rule & Factors
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Second Restatement, what is the general Most Significant Relationship rule and what core factors do courts consider in all cases?
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule (Second Restatement): - Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, the court applies the law of the state that has the most significant relationship to the issue at hand. 2. General Factors Considered in All Cases: - Relevant policies of the forum and other interested jurisdictions. - Relevant policies underlying the substantive field of law. - Ease of applying the candidate law. - Whether applying a given law will aid certainty, uniformity, and predictability in results.
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule (Second Restatement): - Under the {{c1::Most Significant Relationship Approach}} of the {{c2::Second Restatement}}, the court applies the law of the state that has the {{c3::most significant relationship}} to the issue at hand. 2. General Factors Considered in All Cases: - {{c4::Relevant policies of the forum and other interested jurisdictions}}. - {{c5::Relevant policies underlying the substantive field of law}}. - {{c6::Ease of applying the candidate law}}. - Whether applying a given law will aid {{c7::certainty, uniformity, and predictability}}.
cards.easyContent: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, the court applies the law of the state with the most significant relationship to the issue, considering policies of the states, policies of the field, ease of applying the law, and whether the choice promotes certainty and predictability.
cards.mediumContent: The Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach instructs courts to apply the law of the state with the most significant relationship to the issue. To determine this, courts weigh general factors: (1) the policies of the forum and other interested jurisdictions; (2) the policies of the substantive area of law; (3) the ease of applying the candidate law; and (4) whether applying that law furthers certainty, uniformity, and predictability.
cards.hardContent: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, a court selects the law of the state with the most significant relationship to the particular issue. The analysis begins with broad, cross-cutting factors: (1) the relevant policies of the forum and any other interested states; (2) the policies underlying the substantive field (e.g., deterrence in tort, freedom of contract in contracts); (3) the practical ease or difficulty of applying the candidate law; and (4) whether application of that law promotes certainty, uniformity, and predictability in outcomes. These general factors frame and guide the more specific, subject-matter contacts used in later steps.
cards.mnemonic: MSR weighs P-P-E-P: Policies (forum), Policies (field), Ease, Predictability.
cards.clozeLite: Under the Second Restatement, courts apply the law of the state with the {{c1::most significant relationship}} by weighing {{c2::forum and other states’ policies}}, {{c3::policies of the substantive field}}, {{c4::ease of applying the law}}, and {{c5::certainty, uniformity, and predictability}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 005-2. Most Significant Relationship – Torts Contacts
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, what specific contacts do courts focus on in tort cases, and which are most important?
cards.backPlain: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach in tort cases, courts refine the analysis by focusing on tort-specific contacts: 1. Key Tort Contacts: - The place of injury. - The place where the conduct causing the injury occurred. - The residence, domicile, nationality, place of incorporation, and place of business of the parties. 2. Most Significant Factor: - The place of injury and the conduct that caused the injury are typically treated as the most significant factors, especially when they occur in the same state. 3. Overall Goal: - Use these contacts, along with the general MSR factors, to determine which state has the most significant relationship to the tort issue.
cards.cloze: In tort cases under the {{c1::Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach}}, courts focus on: 1. Key Tort Contacts: - The {{c2::place of injury}}. - The {{c3::place where the conduct causing the injury occurred}}. - The {{c4::residence, domicile, nationality, place of incorporation, and place of business of the parties}}. 2. Most Significant Factor: - The {{c5::place of injury and the conduct that caused the injury}} are treated as the {{c6::most significant factors}}, especially when they occur in the same state.
cards.easyContent: For torts, the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship test focuses on the place of injury, the place of the conduct causing injury, and the parties’ domiciles or places of incorporation, with the injury and conduct usually being the most important.
cards.mediumContent: In tort cases, the Most Significant Relationship Approach uses tort-specific contacts: (1) the place of injury; (2) the place where the conduct causing injury occurred; and (3) the residence, domicile, nationality, and place of incorporation or business of the parties. The place of injury and the conduct causing injury are usually the most significant contacts, especially if they coincide in one state.
cards.hardContent: Applying the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach to torts, courts refine the general policy factors by looking closely at tort-related contacts: (1) the place where the injury occurred; (2) the place where the conduct causing the injury occurred; and (3) the residence, domicile, nationality, place of incorporation, and place of business of each party. While all are relevant, the place of injury and the conduct that produced the injury are typically given the greatest weight, particularly when both occur in the same state, because they best capture that state’s regulatory and compensatory interests.
cards.mnemonic: Tort MSR: HURT, HAPPENED, and HOMES of the parties.
cards.clozeLite: Tort MSR focuses on {{c1::place of injury}}, {{c2::place of conduct causing injury}}, and {{c3::parties’ domiciles or places of business}}, with {{c4::injury and conduct usually most important}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 005-3. Most Significant Relationship – Contracts Contacts
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, what specific contacts do courts consider in contract cases, and what default tendency do they apply?
cards.backPlain: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach in contract cases, courts supplement the general factors with contract-specific contacts: 1. Key Contract Contacts: - The place of contracting. - The place of negotiation. - The place of performance. - The location of the subject matter of the contract. - The domicile, residence, nationality, place of incorporation, and place of business of the parties. 2. Default Tendency: - Generally, if the place of negotiation and the place of performance are the same, that forum’s law will be applied because it has the most significant relationship to the contract. 3. Overall Goal: - Use these contacts, along with the general MSR factors, to identify the state with the most significant relationship to the contract dispute.
cards.cloze: In contract cases under the {{c1::Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach}}, courts look to: 1. Key Contract Contacts: - The {{c2::place of contracting}}. - The {{c3::place of negotiation}}. - The {{c4::place of performance}}. - The {{c5::location of the subject matter of the contract}}. - The {{c6::domicile, residence, nationality, place of incorporation, and place of business of the parties}}. 2. Default Tendency: - If the {{c7::place of negotiation and the place of performance are the same}}, courts generally apply {{c8::that forum’s law}} as having the most significant relationship.
cards.easyContent: For contracts, the Most Significant Relationship test looks to the places of contracting, negotiation, and performance, the location of the subject matter, and the parties’ domiciles or incorporation. If negotiation and performance happen in the same state, that state’s law usually applies.
cards.mediumContent: In contract cases, courts applying the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach consider: (1) where the contract was made; (2) where it was negotiated; (3) where it is to be performed; (4) where the subject matter is located; and (5) the domicile, residence, and place of incorporation or business of the parties. As a practical default, if the same state is both the place of negotiation and performance, its law typically governs because it has the most significant relationship.
cards.hardContent: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach to contracts, courts refine the general policies by focusing on contract-centered contacts: (1) the place of contracting; (2) the place of negotiation; (3) the place of performance; (4) the physical location of the subject matter of the contract (e.g., land, goods); and (5) the domicile, residence, nationality, place of incorporation, and place of business of each party. These contacts are weighed together with general policy considerations. As a recurring pattern, where a single state is both the locus of negotiation and the locus of performance, that state is usually found to have the most significant relationship and its law is applied absent strong contrary considerations.
cards.mnemonic: MADE, TALKED, DONE, LOCATED, PARTIES: contract MSR contacts.
cards.clozeLite: Contract MSR looks to {{c1::place of contracting}}, {{c2::negotiation}}, {{c3::performance}}, {{c4::subject matter’s location}}, and {{c5::parties’ domiciles/incorporation}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 005-4. Most Significant Relationship – Property & Corporations
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, what rules do courts use for property and corporation cases when choosing the governing law?
cards.backPlain: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, property and corporation cases are often handled with relatively focused rules: 1. Property Cases: - Courts apply the law of the state that is most significantly related to the property transaction. - In practice, this usually points toward the state where the property is located (especially for interests in land), combined with the general MSR policy factors. 2. Corporation Cases: - Courts typically apply the law of the state where the corporation is incorporated. - That state is generally considered to have the most significant relationship to issues involving the corporation’s internal affairs, such as governance and fiduciary duties.
cards.cloze: Under the {{c1::Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach}}: 1. {{c2::Property}} Cases: - Courts apply the law of the {{c3::state most significantly related to the property transaction}}, which in practice usually means the {{c4::state where the property is located}}, especially for land. 2. {{c5::Corporation}} Cases: - Courts generally apply the law of the {{c6::state where the corporation is incorporated}}, which is treated as having the {{c7::most significant relationship}} to internal corporate affairs.
cards.easyContent: For property, courts under the Most Significant Relationship test use the law of the state most related to the property transaction, usually where the property is located. For corporations, they usually apply the law of the state of incorporation.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach, property disputes are governed by the law of the state most significantly related to the property transaction, typically the state where the property (especially land) is located. For corporations, courts usually apply the law of the state of incorporation to issues involving corporate internal affairs, on the theory that it has the most significant relationship.
cards.hardContent: Applying the Second Restatement’s Most Significant Relationship Approach to property, courts choose the law of the state most significantly related to the property transaction. This typically points to the situs state—especially for real property—because that state has the strongest regulatory and stability interests in land and property rights, though the general MSR factors still inform the analysis. For corporations, courts almost always apply the law of the state of incorporation to internal affairs issues (such as governance, shareholder rights, and fiduciary duties), reflecting the view that the incorporating state has the most significant relationship to the corporation’s internal structure and responsibilities.
cards.clozeLite: Under MSR, {{c1::property disputes}} use the law of the {{c2::state most related, usually the situs}}, while {{c3::corporate internal affairs}} use {{c4::state of incorporation}} law.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.topic: Recognition of Divorce Judgments – General Full Faith and Credit Rule
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 008-1. Recognition of Divorce Judgments – General Full Faith and Credit Rule
cards.front: Recognition of Divorce Decrees – General Rule
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general full faith and credit rule for when a state must recognize another state’s divorce decree?
cards.backPlain: General Rule for Recognition of Divorce Decrees: 1. Full Faith and Credit Requirement: 1.1 A state must give full faith and credit to a divorce decree issued by a sister state if BOTH of the following are satisfied: (a) The decree is valid under the law of the rendering (issuing) state; and (b) The rendering state had proper jurisdiction. 2. Jurisdiction Basis: 2.1 Proper jurisdiction for a divorce decree is ordinarily satisfied if at least one of the spouses is domiciled in the state that granted the divorce. 3. Effect: 3.1 When these requirements are met, other states must recognize the divorce status and its legal effects (e.g., marital status, ability to remarry), subject to specific exceptions for issues like property, support, and custody that may have separate jurisdictional rules.
cards.cloze: General Rule for {{c1::Recognition of Divorce Decrees}}: 1. {{c2::Full Faith and Credit}} Requirement: 1.1 A state must give full faith and credit to a divorce decree issued by a sister state if BOTH of the following are satisfied: (a) The decree is {{c3::valid under the law of the rendering state}}; and (b) The rendering state had {{c4::proper jurisdiction}}. 2. Jurisdiction Basis: 2.1 Proper jurisdiction is ordinarily satisfied if at least {{c5::one spouse is domiciled}} in the state that granted the divorce. 3. Effect: 3.1 When these requirements are met, other states must {{c6::recognize the divorce status and its legal effects}}.
cards.easyContent: A state must recognize another state’s divorce decree if it is valid where issued and that court had jurisdiction, which is usually based on at least one spouse being domiciled there.
cards.mediumContent: Under full faith and credit, a sister-state divorce decree must be recognized if it is valid under the law of the rendering state and that court had proper jurisdiction. For divorce, jurisdiction is ordinarily satisfied when at least one spouse is domiciled in the rendering state. If both validity and jurisdiction are present, other states must give full effect to the divorce.
cards.hardContent: The general rule for recognition of divorce decrees across state lines is governed by the Full Faith and Credit Clause. An enforcing state must recognize a divorce decree rendered by another state if: (1) the decree is valid under the substantive and procedural law of the rendering state; and (2) the rendering court had proper jurisdiction to grant the divorce. In the divorce context, jurisdiction is typically established through domicile—if at least one spouse is domiciled in the rendering state at the time of the decree, jurisdiction is ordinarily sufficient. When these conditions are met, other states must recognize the parties’ changed marital status and related legal consequences, subject to separate jurisdictional analysis for collateral issues like property division, alimony, and custody.
cards.mnemonic: V + J + D: Valid, Jurisdiction, Domicile for divorce.
cards.clozeLite: A sister-state {{c1::divorce decree}} must be recognized if it is {{c2::valid under the rendering state’s law}} and the court had {{c3::jurisdiction based on at least one spouse’s domicile}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.topic: Recognition of Divorce Judgments – Ex Parte vs. Consent Divorces and Domicile
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 008-2. Recognition of Divorce Judgments – Ex Parte vs. Consent Divorces and Domicile
cards.front: Ex Parte vs. Consent Divorces – Recognition and Domicile
cards.frontPrompt: How do ex parte divorces differ from consent divorces for purposes of full faith and credit, and what role does domicile play?
cards.backPlain: Ex Parte vs. Consent Divorces and Domicile: 1. Ex Parte Divorce (One-Spouse Domicile/Appearance): 1.1 Definition: A divorce where only one spouse appears and the decree is based on that spouse’s domicile in the rendering state. 1.2 Domicile Inquiry: - The enforcing state may examine whether the rendering spouse’s claimed domicile in the divorcing state was bona fide. - There is a rebuttable presumption that the spouse’s domicile as found by the rendering court is genuine. 1.3 Recognition Consequence: - If domicile was genuine and jurisdiction proper, the decree must be given full faith and credit as to marital status. 2. Consent Divorce (Both Spouses Participate): 2.1 Definition: A divorce where both spouses appear (often by personal appearance or valid consent) before the rendering court. 2.2 Jurisdiction and Domicile: - Full faith and credit will be given if the rendering court had proper jurisdiction. - Jurisdiction will be found when at least one spouse is domiciled in the forum; if both are properly domiciled, jurisdiction is especially secure. 2.3 Recognition Consequence: - Other states must generally recognize the decree and may not collaterally attack jurisdiction as easily as in an ex parte divorce. 3. Key Contrast: 3.1 Ex parte divorces are more vulnerable to collateral attacks on domicile and jurisdiction in the enforcing state. 3.2 Consent divorces, with both spouses present and at least one domiciled in the forum, receive stronger full faith and credit protection.
cards.cloze: Ex Parte vs. Consent Divorces and Domicile: 1. {{c1::Ex Parte Divorce}} (One-Spouse Domicile/Appearance): 1.1 A divorce where only {{c2::one spouse appears}} and the decree is based on that spouse’s {{c3::domicile}} in the rendering state. 1.2 The enforcing state may {{c4::examine whether domicile was bona fide}}, although there is a {{c5::rebuttable presumption}} that the domicile found by the rendering court is {{c6::genuine}}. 2. {{c7::Consent Divorce}} (Both Spouses Participate): 2.1 Both spouses {{c8::appear or consent}} before the rendering court. 2.2 Full faith and credit will be given if the court had {{c9::proper jurisdiction}}, which is satisfied when at least {{c10::one spouse is domiciled}} in the forum (and is especially strong if both are domiciled). 3. Key Contrast: 3.1 Ex parte divorces are more vulnerable to {{c11::collateral attacks on domicile and jurisdiction}}. 3.2 Consent divorces receive {{c12::stronger full faith and credit protection}} because both spouses were before the rendering court.
cards.easyContent: In ex parte divorces, only one spouse appears and the enforcing state can reexamine whether that spouse’s domicile in the rendering state was real, though domicile is presumed bona fide. In consent divorces, both spouses appear and if at least one is domiciled in the forum, jurisdiction is strong and other states must generally honor the decree.
cards.mediumContent: An ex parte divorce is granted when only one spouse appears before the rendering court, typically based on that spouse’s domicile. The enforcing state may reexamine whether that domicile was genuine, although the rendering court’s domicile finding is presumed correct but rebuttable. A consent divorce occurs when both spouses participate in the proceeding; if at least one spouse is domiciled in the forum, jurisdiction exists and other states must generally give full faith and credit. Ex parte decrees are thus more susceptible to collateral jurisdictional attack than consent decrees.
cards.hardContent: Ex parte divorces and consent divorces differ in how easily other states may challenge the rendering court’s jurisdiction. An ex parte divorce is granted on the basis of only one spouse’s appearance and alleged domicile in the rendering state. While domicile provides the jurisdictional hook for the decree, an enforcing state is permitted to inquire into whether that domicile was bona fide, despite a rebuttable presumption favoring the rendering court’s domicile determination. By contrast, a consent divorce involves both spouses appearing or consenting to the jurisdiction of the rendering court. Where at least one spouse is domiciled in the forum (and especially when both are domiciled there), jurisdiction is secure, and sister states must give the decree full faith and credit with far less room to collaterally attack the jurisdictional basis. Thus, ex parte divorces are more vulnerable to challenges on domicile and jurisdiction than consent divorces.
cards.mnemonic: Ex Parte = Examine domicile; Consent = Confirmed jurisdiction.
cards.clozeLite: In an {{c1::ex parte divorce}}, only one spouse appears and other states may {{c2::reexamine domicile}}. In a {{c3::consent divorce}}, {{c4::both spouses participate}} and {{c5::jurisdiction is generally secure}}.

cards.subject: Conflicts Of Law
cards.topic: Recognition of Divorce Judgments – Child Custody Jurisdiction and Modification
cards.rawHeader: Conflicts Of Law 008-3. Recognition of Divorce Judgments – Child Custody Jurisdiction and Modification
cards.front: Child Custody Orders – Home State Jurisdiction and Modification
cards.frontPrompt: How is jurisdiction over child custody determinations established and retained across states, and when may another state modify an existing custody order?
cards.backPlain: Child Custody Jurisdiction and Recognition: 1. Governing Law: 1.1 Child custody determinations are governed by reciprocal statutes adopted by all states (e.g., UCCJEA), not just general divorce full faith and credit principles. 2. Initial Jurisdiction – Home State Rule: 2.1 A court has jurisdiction to make an initial custody determination if it is the child’s "home state." - The child’s home state is generally where the child has lived with a parent (or person acting as a parent) for the required statutory period immediately before the proceeding. 2.2 When a court properly exercises home-state jurisdiction and issues a custody order, all other states must give that determination full faith and credit. 3. Continuing Jurisdiction and Modification: 3.1 The court that made the original custody decree retains exclusive, continuing jurisdiction over custody. 3.2 No other state may modify that custody determination unless: - The original court determines that it no longer has a significant connection with the child or the parties; or - The original court otherwise relinquishes or loses jurisdiction under the statute (e.g., everyone has moved out of the state). 4. Effect of these Rules: 4.1 Prevents competing custody orders from different states. 4.2 Ensures stability by centralizing authority in the child’s home state until that state no longer has a significant connection to the child or the parties.
cards.cloze: Child Custody Jurisdiction and Recognition: 1. Governing Law: 1.1 Child custody determinations are governed by {{c1::reciprocal statutes}} adopted by all states (e.g., {{c2::UCCJEA}}). 2. Initial Jurisdiction – {{c3::Home State Rule}}: 2.1 A court has jurisdiction to make an initial custody determination if it is the child’s {{c4::home state}}. 2.2 When a court properly exercises home-state jurisdiction and issues a custody order, all other states must give that determination {{c5::full faith and credit}}. 3. Continuing Jurisdiction and Modification: 3.1 The court that made the original custody decree {{c6::retains exclusive, continuing jurisdiction}}. 3.2 No other state may {{c7::modify}} that custody determination unless the original court has {{c8::no significant connection}} with the child or the parties (or otherwise loses or relinquishes jurisdiction under the statute). 4. Effect: 4.1 These rules prevent {{c9::competing custody orders}} and promote {{c10::stability}} in the child’s custody arrangements.
cards.easyContent: Custody is governed by uniform home-state statutes. The child’s home state has jurisdiction to make the initial custody order, and other states must honor it. The original court keeps exclusive, continuing jurisdiction and other states can’t modify the order unless the original court no longer has a significant connection with the child or parties.
cards.mediumContent: Child custody jurisdiction is determined by reciprocal statutes such as the UCCJEA. A state court has authority to make an initial custody determination if it is the child’s home state, typically where the child has lived with a parent for the statutory period. Once a valid home-state custody order issues, other states must give it full faith and credit. The issuing court retains exclusive, continuing jurisdiction, and another state may not modify the order unless the original court no longer has a significant connection with the child or the parties, or otherwise loses jurisdiction under the statute.
cards.hardContent: Unlike divorce status, which is governed primarily by the Full Faith and Credit Clause and domicile, child custody determinations are controlled by reciprocal jurisdictional statutes such as the UCCJEA. A court has authority to make an initial custody determination if it is the child’s home state, defined (by statute) as the state where the child lived with a parent or person acting as a parent for the requisite period immediately preceding the commencement of the proceeding. Once a home-state court issues a custody decree, other states must recognize and enforce that order, giving it full faith and credit. The issuing court retains exclusive, continuing jurisdiction so long as it maintains a significant connection with the child or the parties and substantial evidence concerning the child’s care and relationships remains there. Another state may not modify the existing custody order unless the original court determines it no longer has such a significant connection, or all relevant parties have left the state, thereby relinquishing or losing jurisdiction under the statute.
cards.mnemonic: Home Holds: home state holds custody jurisdiction until ties fade.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::UCCJEA}}, the child’s {{c2::home state}} makes the initial custody order and keeps {{c3::exclusive, continuing jurisdiction}} until it loses a {{c4::significant connection}} with the child or parties.
